titleInfo.title: Coll 30/217 'American Oil Mission to Middle East (Anglo-U.S. Oil Agreement).'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the inside front cover with 1, and terminates at the last folio with 352; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-352; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file concerns the United States (US) Government-sanctioned Oil Mission to the Middle East, 1943, and subsequent talks between delegations sponsored by the British and US Governments, which led to the publication of the Anglo-US Oil Agreement in 1944, the purpose of which was to manage international oil supply and demand. A revised text of the agreement was signed in September 1945, but the agreement was not subsequently ratified by the US Government.The papers include: background papers on British Government oil policy, 1943-44, including one document dated 1934 (folios 283-352); India Office telegram dated 31 October 1943, concerning the political aspects of the preponderant US oil contribution to the Allied war effort (folio 281); papers concerning the US Oil Mission to the Middle East, 1943; papers concerning the proposed US Government oil pipeline from Dhahran in Saudi Arabia to a point in the Mediterranean; the influence of domestic US politics on the Anglo-US talks; India Office 'Memorandum on the Concessions in the Arab Sheikhdoms of the Persian Gulf', dated 1 March 1944 (folios 191-199); reports from the British Embassy, Washington on the progress of the talks; United States No. 1 (1944) Agreement on Petroleum between the Government of the United States of America and the Government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, 1944 (folios 62-64); reports of opposition to the agreement by the US oil industry, 1944; discussion by the US Government of a revised text of the proposed agreement, February 1945; and further Anglo-US talks on renegotiating the oil agreement, 1946-47.The file also includes correspondence from the Foreign Office, the Ministry of Fuel and Power, the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, and the Government of India.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
